Michael was stuck there for a long time, feeling unhappy and ashamed. Eventually, he jumped down and walked home, feeling sad and wanting to avoid his friends.

When he got home, his stepmother was angry with him for being late for dinner. She told him to stay in for the night. Michael was still thinking about his friends laughing at him and felt miserable.

Chocolate is a popular treat that comes from South America. Today, it's a big business worth millions of pounds. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter. It's a time when eight per cent of all chocolate is sold. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate.

The history of chocolate goes back over 3,000 years to the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilisations in Central America. They grew the cacao tree, which is a tropical plant found in many parts of the world. The fruit of the tree has 20-40 seeds, which are called cacao beans. These beans are used to make chocolate.

In the past, the Aztecs used cacao beans as money and to make a special drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water' in their language. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar. Chocolate houses were popular in Europe's capital cities, where people would gather to drink chocolate.

In the 19th century, a Dutch inventor created chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. Later, a British company called Fry and Sons created the first chocolate bars. A Swiss company added milk to the process, making milk chocolate. Today, many chocolate companies are looking for new ways to attract customers, such as making chocolate-flavored ice cream and soft drinks.

Unfortunately, many small-scale cacao farmers struggled when cocoa bean prices dropped in the 1980s. As a result, many were forced to stop farming. Next time you eat a chocolate bar, remember the farmers who work hard to grow the beans.<|eot_id|>

There are also human mistakes or accidents that can happen. Large airports, called hubs, can be especially busy and mistakes can happen more often. For example, London's Heathrow airport is very busy and many people transfer planes there. 

To avoid losing your luggage, try to take a direct flight. Check in early and make sure your luggage is labeled correctly. Here is a simplified version of the text for a B1 learner:

If you want to take your children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to try out the best ones. Here's what they thought:

Fun Island - The Burns family

We went to Fun Island with our three-year-old. We thought it might be boring compared to a big theme park in the US. But we were surprised. The park is great for young children, so our three-year-old had a lot of fun. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There's even a special ride for very young children. For older kids, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! We were tired after five hours, but the kids didn't want to leave. We thought the park could improve its atmosphere and scenery, but the staff were very helpful and the park was clean and well-organized.

Wonderland - The McMillan family

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought our little boy might be too young, but he loved it. He loved the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small replicas of famous buildings. The older kids enjoyed the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road. We spent six hours there and were glad there were places to rest. The park is very well-designed and the staff are friendly.

Adventure World - The Jeffree family

After seven hours, we still had a lot to see. The kids loved the Big Top Circus and the Terror Line, which was a bit scary for them. They also liked Running River, which is like a river ride. For younger kids, Toy Land is great fun. We were impressed with how well the park is designed, even the queues aren't boring. The park is very clean and the staff are great.

The Great Park - The Langridge family

We went to The Great Park and were a bit disappointed that it only opened until 5 pm. It's a great park for young children, with rides that aren't too scary. Even I, who's a bit scared, had fun. We loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then gets exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, but it was over before we knew it!

Fantasy World - The Break-all family

Fantasy World has a big roller-coaster called the Rocket, which is the tallest in Europe. Our son thought it was the scariest ride, but our daughter said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down, was even worse! There are many main rides that the older kids went on several times. Our younger child was too small for some of them, but enjoyed the Long Slide. We thought the staff were a bit mixed, some were great with the young children, but not all of them were friendly. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World.

Kendra says her whole life is about getting ready for the Championships. She has a strict schedule to improve her fitness. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 teams participating.

Kendra is excited to have home support, which is special. She wants to improve the reputation of netball in England and make the country proud. The World Championships are different from other competitions. There's no rest between games, and you can still win even if you lose the first game. But if you lose, you only get one chance to make it up.

Kendra has been playing netball for 15 years, and the game has become faster and more competitive. Players are more aggressive, but Kendra says they're all friends after the game.

Netball is also using new methods to test fitness. Kendra thinks it's important to be a strong leader and set a good example for her team. She's been planning her netball career carefully and has decided that this will be her last big competition as a player.

Here is a simplified version of the text for a B1 learner:

**Special Music Schools for Gifted Children**

When a child shows exceptional musical talent, it can be difficult to know how to help them develop their skills. Many parents may not recognize their child's gift until they start to behave badly because they are frustrated. Regular schools can't always provide the special support that musically gifted children need. This is why specialist music schools were created.

There are five specialist music schools in Britain that offer a special environment for children aged 7-18 to learn and practice music with professional musicians. These schools provide a balance between music lessons and normal school subjects like English, maths, and science. The schools have small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio.

Most students at these schools are boarders, which means they live at the school and attend classes full-time. This helps them focus on their music and make friends with others who share their passion.

However, there are some disadvantages to consider. The schools are expensive, with fees ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 per year. Some parents may also worry about sending their child to boarding school at a young age.

Some people think that setting children apart from their peers too early can be stressful and may even cause their musical talent to disappear. The schools try to monitor each student's progress and offer help if needed.

Not all students who attend these schools feel that the academic program is good enough. Some are very intelligent and can handle academic pressure, but feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met. It might be better to wait until the child is old enough to make their own decisions about their education.

There are other options for musically gifted children, such as attending a school with a strong music department or taking extra music lessons at a music college. However, these options may not be available for families who live far from major cities.<|eot_id|>

Are you trying to get your writing published? Margaret Stubbs is here to help. Many people write to us asking, "Where should I send my story?" Before you start, you need to know about the publishing industry and improve your writing skills. To do this, read widely and research the market. Look for books and magazines that are similar to what you want to write. Visit your local library and bookshops to find out what's popular.

If you're not sure what you want to write about, start by reading different types of stories and magazines. For example, if you like writing love stories, find out which magazines publish them and read recent issues.

Some writers send me their work and ask if it's any good. As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone, but most new writers are not ready to be published yet. It's better to keep writing and improving your skills before sending your work out. When you do send your work, don't stop writing. Keep writing more stories and articles, and each one will be better than the last. Don't be afraid to make mistakes and don't show your work to others until you're sure it's ready.

I was leaning against a pillar, watching everyone, when I saw a well-dressed man talking to people. He asked a woman if she was going to Philadelphia, and then he moved on to ask another person. I was curious about him, so I listened as he talked to more people. He was looking for someone who was going to Philadelphia, but nobody seemed to be going there.

I was going to Philadelphia myself, but he didn't ask me. I think he didn't ask me because I didn't look like someone who could help him. He was getting more and more worried as he talked to people. Finally, he found a woman who was going to Philadelphia, and he asked her for a favour. He told her that his daughter was flying out of Philadelphia and had forgotten her passport. He had sent his daughter to the station with her passport, but then he realized that he had left the passport at home. He asked the woman if she could take the passport to his daughter.

The woman was kind and offered to help. She asked him why he didn't go to the station himself, but he said his wife was in a wheelchair and he couldn't leave her alone. I didn't think this was a good excuse, and I thought the man was trying to trick the woman. I was watching him closely, and I noticed that he was holding a padded envelope. I thought it might be important, so I was careful.

Here is a simplified version of the text, suitable for a B1 level learner:

People love dolphins. They are very intelligent and can understand human emotions. We see them in movies and TV shows, but their situation is actually very serious. According to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, their numbers are decreasing.

Dolphins have a special place in our hearts. They are known for their intelligence and ability to communicate with humans. However, this love affair is not entirely true. The reality is that dolphins are struggling in the polluted and overfished oceans of the 20th century.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises has decreased by up to 89,000. You might expect these popular animals to be protected by law and cared for in special marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not the case, and it may become one of the biggest wildlife disasters of our time.

There are 40 different types of dolphins worldwide. In European waters, the most common ones are the striped, common, bottlenose, and harbour porpoise dolphins. The first two are usually found far out at sea and are rarely seen. The bottlenose and harbour porpoise dolphins, on the other hand, used to be common near European coasts. They are now mostly found in Scotland and Wales, and they show signs of stress.

It's difficult to determine the exact reason for the decline in dolphin numbers. Overfishing, which is reducing the world's fish stocks and threatening local fishing industries, also affects porpoises and dolphins. Dolphins need to find food quickly, and if fish in one area are removed, they may not survive to find food elsewhere. They are also at risk of getting caught in fishermen's nets, which are often invisible to them.

In recent years, many dead dolphins have been found on French and Cornish beaches, with signs of injury from being caught in nets. Dolphins can also store waste and pollutants in their bodies, which can be harmful to them. For example, pesticides can build up in their fat and be passed on to their babies through their milk. There have already been cases of young dolphins being poisoned by their mother's milk.

Human disturbance is another major threat to dolphins. They live in groups and communicate through sound, and noise pollution from ships, oil wells, and other sources can disturb them in ways we don't yet understand.

* Shortened sentences and paragraphs to make them easier to follow

* Removed complex ideas and concepts
* Added transitional phrases to connect ideas and make the text flow better
* Changed the tone to make it more accessible and easy to understand for a B1 level learner.<|eot_id|>

It can also help you lose weight and improve your overall health.

Remember to start slowly and carefully, especially if you're new to exercise. It's also a good idea to talk to your doctor before starting a new exercise routine. Good posture is important, as it can affect how you look and feel. Imagine your head is connected to a balloon, and it's trying to lift you up. This can help you stand up straight and breathe more easily.

Stretching is also important. It helps improve your flexibility and makes it easier to move around. It can also help prevent injuries. You should stretch four or five times a week to stay flexible and fit. The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, a workout, and a cool-down.

**First Impressions Matter**

When we meet someone for the first time, we often make a judgment about them in just a few minutes. We notice how they dress, how they talk, and how they move. Mary Pearce, a teacher, learned this the hard way. She had a small hole in her jacket during an interview, but she didn't change because she was already running late. Unfortunately, the interviewer thought she didn't care about her appearance, and that was a problem.

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, agrees. He says that people who take care of their appearance are more likely to care about their job. Many people forget to dress professionally, like Janet Goodwood, who didn't get an interview for a promotion because of her clothes.

Our body language also matters. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 55% of our message comes from our facial expressions. If our words and facial expressions don't match, the listener will pay more attention to our body language.

It's also important not to seem too eager or desperate for a job. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, got a job offer, but she reacted too excitedly and got a lower salary than she expected.

Finally, knowing about the company and preparing questions to ask during the interview can help. David Artesio, a manager, suggests looking at the company's annual report and mentioning areas that interest you. Business consultant Marian Woodall recommends speaking in short sentences and having a few questions ready.

**Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

A. Darius (runner)
I've always been into sports. I tried many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I had a tryout for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country's youth team and getting a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much attention in the media. But you have to be disciplined. If friends ask me to go out the night before training, I have to say no. My goal is to get to the next Olympics.

B. Gabriel (surfer)
The surfing community is small, so you see the same people everywhere you compete. Professional surfers are serious and often the best waves are at dawn. You have to cut out late nights if you want to get good. I don't mind, but I do love sleeping in. But it's worth it because without dedication, I might not have won the National Championships. After a big win, I like to celebrate with a big night out. And, of course, the sacrifices are worth it in the long run.

C. Dieter (yacht racer)
When we're on a boat with five friends, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and like to celebrate a win with a big party. Sometimes reporters are more interested in where we go out and what we do there than in our sailing skills. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's great to come back and do normal things with my friends. You can't live and breathe sailing all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known in the sailing world, but I'm not a celebrity. I get nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I always reply.

D. Tomas (tennis player)
It's great to walk onto the court and feel the crowd supporting me. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around. I do get a thrill when fans recognize me when I'm out shopping or something. But it has its downsides. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players have to travel a lot, and that's why we split up. You have to make sacrifices in any sport. Ice Skating

Ice skating has a long history. Archaeologists have found old skates made from animal bones. People used these skates until iron was introduced in Scandinavia about 2,000 years ago. In the past, only rich people could afford to skate. But in the 1920s, a young girl named Sonja Henie changed the way people skated. She made it more fun and exciting.

Now, ice skating combines art and sport. It's a great way to stay fit and have fun. To start, you need to learn how to balance and control your movements. Keep your knees bent and your body centered. Relaxing is also important. You should keep your heels together and your feet turned outwards.

To move on the ice, you need to make small movements with your feet. Start with short movements and gradually increase the distance as you get more comfortable. It's normal to fall, even for experienced skaters. To avoid getting hurt, try to relax and roll with the fall.

Once you're comfortable on the ice, you can try different styles, such as figure skating, free skating, or skating with a partner. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then moving on to free skating. Most ice rinks offer lessons and guidance to help you learn.

To improve your skating, you should practice regularly and do exercises to loosen up your muscles. This will help you move more smoothly and easily on the ice. Skating can also improve your balance, coordination, and overall health.

Now, most people eat the same three foods - wheat, rice, and maize - which are not very good for us.

This poor diet has made people unhealthy and short. In the past, people who ate these foods were not as strong and healthy as those who ate a variety of foods. But now, some countries are starting to eat more like our ancestors did, and this is making people taller again.

In the US, the average height is 179 cm, in Holland it is 180 cm, and in Japan it is 177 cm. This is good news, but it also means that we need to make our buildings and clothes bigger. Scientists think that the average height of people could reach 193 cm in the future.

However, some scientists also think that we might actually be getting smaller as a species. During the last ice age, our ancestors were taller and rounder because it was cold. Now that it's warmer, we are getting thinner and smaller. This means that our height might not keep growing forever.

I visited a kite-flying festival in Malaysia with a friend named Adnan. He gave me a kite as a gift because the string had broken. I was surprised and asked him why. He said it's a tradition in Malaysia - if the string breaks, the finder gets to keep the kite. He showed me his many kites, all the same size and made of special paper and bamboo.

We sat under some trees and looked out at the festival. There were 10 platforms where people held up their kites, and many people waiting to let their kites fly. When the whistle blew, the kites went up in the air like rockets. There were over 500 people competing, and they had to make four different kites each. Adnan told me that making kites is not easy, but flying them is not so hard.

Adnan invited me to visit him at his home, and I accepted. He showed me around and we had tea and snacks. He said I could come back the next day to help him make a new kite, but I didn't have time. Instead, I drove to a nearby town and then got lost in the forest. I met a man named Baba who had a tent and some huts, and I decided to stay there. The night was dark and noisy, but I was too tired to worry about the insects. The next morning, I woke up to a beautiful view of the mountains. It rained later, and I got wet, but I was relieved to find my car was still there at the bottom of the track.

When I got back to the city, everyone was friendly and curious. They asked me where I was from and how old I was, but it was all friendly. I remember my trip to Kelantan more for the kind people than the kites.<|eot_id|>

I. Linda, a restaurant manager, is an unwilling shopper. She only goes shopping when she has to and doesn't like trying on clothes.

Here is the simplified text:

What is money? Money is like a unit of measurement, like a gram or a kilometre. But unlike these units, money can be exchanged for things we want or need. A five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that doesn't cost much to make.

A long time ago, people didn't have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Instead, people traded things with each other. For example, a farmer might exchange the corn he grew for some honey from a beekeeper. This was a direct exchange between two people who had something the other wanted.

As time went on, most societies created their own special money, so people could trade more easily. Different types of money started to join together, which is why we use national currencies today.<|eot_id|>

Many people climb Ben Nevis, a mountain in Scotland, every year. It's a big challenge because of its cold weather. I, Keith Hewitt, climbed Ben Nevis for the first time in February. We went up the north face to Tower Ridge, which is 600 meters high. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls cut into the mountain. We took our tents, sleeping bags, and special spikes for our boots because the snow was very hard and slippery.

We also brought safety equipment, like lights, hard hats, and extra clothes. Although the weather was good, we were still a bit nervous. Ben Nevis is always a challenge in the winter. The track was steep and my legs felt heavy. I had to rest more often because I was the weakest member of the group. The others would stop to let me catch up, but then they would start moving again. I promised myself to train better before a climb next time.

After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge. It's very narrow, only 1.5 meters wide, and the mountain drops down hundreds of meters on each side. We had to be very careful and concentrate as we walked along it. It took us seven hours to reach the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we weren't lucky that day because a mist came down. Getting back down to camp can be just as difficult as going up. We had to read the map carefully to make sure we didn't take a wrong turn. I was glad we took turns doing this job. When I was finally safe in my tent, I realized I had really enjoyed the experience.<|eot_id|>

One thing that's different is that there are no heaters in the school. Instead, the heat comes from us, the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep the heat inside, and it's also very quiet. If we sing in class, it feels like we're in a concert hall!

THE ICEHOTEL

For a long time, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer. But in the winter, the few people who lived there had the snow and ice all to themselves. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to show his work in a special snow building in a small town called Jukkasjarvi. The building was called Arctic Hall and many people came to visit. One night, a group of tourists decided to sleep in Arctic Hall. They liked it so much that they thought it would be a good idea to build a whole hotel made of ice and snow. And that's exactly what they did.

Now, every year, a team of builders, architects, and artists come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They work on different parts of the hotel at the same time, so some parts are ready for visitors while others are still being built. The hotel is finished in January, and then it melts in the spring when it gets warmer.

Inside the hotel, it's never colder than -5°C to -8°C, even if it's very cold outside. Guests can borrow warm clothes, like overalls, hats, and gloves, and they can also bring their own warm clothes to wear. If you want to visit the hotel, you can buy warm clothes and other things you need on the hotel's website. They will deliver them to your room when you arrive.

The hotel is in a village called Jukkasjarvi, which is 200 km above the Arctic Circle. It's close to Kiruna airport and train station, and you can take a bus from there to the hotel.

**The Short Story Society**

The Short Story Society helps writers in the UK. It was started in 1899 and is now one of the most active arts organizations in the country.

**Magazines**

We publish two magazines. The first one is called Short Story Review. It has short stories by famous British writers and also gives new writers the chance to publish their work. The second magazine is Short Story News. It has interviews with writers and information about writing events, competitions, and festivals.

**National Short Story Competition**

We run a big competition for short stories. Anyone aged 18 or over can enter. The stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no entry fee for members, but non-members need to pay £5. The competition runs from April to October. The top 10 stories will be published in our annual book of short stories. The winner will get a publishing contract to publish their own book of short stories.

**Education**

For nearly 30 years, we have been going into schools to help writers, both children and teachers. We have projects like the Young Writer of the Year, which is for writers aged 11-18. The winners get book prizes and can attend a five-day writing course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe is our social center. It's a relaxed and stylish place with vegetarian food, coffee, and drinks. We also have exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It's in the heart of London and is open from 11am to 10pm from Monday to Friday and 11am to 8pm on Saturday. Members get discounts on some products and events.

**Joining the Society**

We have members all over the world. Anyone aged 18 or over can join us. If you want to join, click here and fill out the registration form.<|eot_id|>

A team of safety divers watched her dive.

Some people think free-diving is too dangerous, but Tanya says safety is the most important thing. She trains a lot to make sure she is prepared. She spends most of her time training on land, in the pool, and in the ocean. She also uses a special bike to improve her heart fitness. She doesn't run because it can hurt her knees, but she likes to walk fast to stay fit.

When Tanya is not training, she travels to different places to do practice dives. She does 14 dives in four weeks, with a day off in between. She has to stay fit to do this. When she's not training, she does public appearances to advertise sports products and help environmental organizations. She grew up on a Caribbean island and loved swimming and exploring the ocean. She feels like she's living her childhood dream now.

Tanya is now in her thirties and plans to keep breaking her own world records. She didn't start free-diving until she was 25, so she doesn't plan to stop for many years.

'A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER

The MV Lady Ivy May is a special ship that takes people on a trip along the Douro river in Portugal. The ship can carry 160 people and has comfortable cabins with private showers and toilets. On the ship, you'll find a sunny deck, a lounge, a bar, a dining room, a shop, and a library.

Day 1: We will fly from London to Oporto in the evening. Your guide will meet you and take you to the ship, where you'll spend the night.

Day 2: We'll visit Oporto in the morning, then go back to the ship and start our journey up the river. It will take about four hours to get to Entre-os-Rios.

Day 3: We'll keep going up the river. In the evening, we'll stop at Peso da Regua, where you can try some delicious food and drink.

Day 4: After breakfast, we'll go to the ancient town of Lamego by bus. We'll visit the cathedral, some churches, and a museum. The museum is in a old palace and has many beautiful paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Then we'll go back to the ship and continue our journey.

Day 5: The river gets narrower here, and sometimes we might need to take a smaller boat to the Spanish border. If we can't take the boat, we'll go by coach instead.

Day 6: In the morning, we'll go to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a beautiful view. Then we'll have lunch on the ship and take a train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the ship will be waiting for us.

Day 7: We'll visit Vila Real and then go back to the ship for lunch. In the afternoon, we'll go back down the river to Oporto.

Day 8: We'll arrive in Oporto in the morning, and you can spend some time exploring on your own before we fly back to London.'

This has brought many students to the city, and Norwich is now a popular place for shopping, eating out, and entertainment.

The city also has a football team, which is called 'The Canaries'. Nobody knows why it's called this, but the team plays in green and yellow colours. The city has a new shopping centre called 'The Castle Mall', which was built on a big hole in the city centre. Every autumn, the city of Albuquerque in the United States has a big balloon festival. The festival started in 1972 to celebrate a local radio station's 50th birthday. At first, there were only a few balloons, but now there are over a thousand balloons from all around the world.

The balloons are very colorful and come in different shapes, like animals and cartoon characters. You can walk around and talk to the pilots who are preparing their balloons for take-off. In the evening, you can see the balloons light up their burners and take off into the sky. This is called a "balloon glow" and it's a great time to take photos.

You can also take a balloon ride over the desert or ride a cable car to the top of the nearby mountains for a great view of the festival. There are many other things to do, like balloon races and fireworks.

The Albuquerque Box is a special wind pattern that makes it easy for balloonists to control their balloons. It's a great place to visit, but you should buy your tickets in advance to avoid waiting. Wear comfortable clothing and bring a flashlight for the night events. Don't forget your camera and sunscreen!

A long time ago, in the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state in the USA. Many people came to the area to search for gold. A town called Iditarod grew quickly and became the largest city in Alaska. In the summer, people could bring supplies to the town by boat. But in the winter, the rivers and ocean froze, and it was hard to get to the town. So, in 1910, a special path was built for dogs to pull sleds. They would bring mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. The path was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for the dogs to travel across Alaska. They stopped at special houses along the way where the drivers could rest and feed their dogs.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s, when planes became a better way to travel. But in 1925, a big problem happened. A disease called diphtheria spread to the town of Nome. The only medicine to cure it was in Anchorage, but it was too far away. No one knew if planes could fly in the cold weather, and the only pilot who could do it was away on a trip. So, it was decided to send the medicine by dog sled instead. Twenty teams of dogs made the journey, which was over 1,000 kilometers long. They followed the Iditarod Trail and took six days to complete it. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian, and his dog Togo went the first part of the way. Then Gunnar Kaasen and his dog Saito finished the journey. One of the dogs, Balto, was very brave and helped the team avoid danger. Because of Balto's bravery, the disease was stopped, and he became a hero.

Today, every year, a dog sled race is held from Anchorage to Nome, following the same route as the famous journey in 1925. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.<|eot_id|>

Before booking a flight, here's what you need to know:

We take tourists on a special plane from Sydney, Australia to Antarctica and back during the short Antarctic summer. The flight is about 12 hours long. You'll get two boarding passes. At the halfway point, you'll move to the seat on your second pass. Business and first class passengers will have a window seat for half the flight, while economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half the flight.

While we're over Antarctica, feel free to get up and move around the plane to see the amazing sights. The pilot will fly the plane in special shapes to make sure everyone can see everything.

What if the weather is bad? We have 17 different flight plans, and the captain chooses the best one based on the weather forecast.

Will I see penguins and other wildlife? Unfortunately, most Antarctic animals live at sea level, so we can't see them in detail. We don't land on Antarctica because of environmental reasons. If you want to see Antarctic wildlife, you should join a boat tour.

Can I take photos? Yes! All cameras are welcome, and we even have some fun photo opportunities where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Here is the simplified text for a B1 learner:

Winter driving can be very dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen and accidents can happen quickly. Fog can suddenly appear on the road, and hidden ice can make the road slippery. A car coming towards you might slide across the road, and it's hard to control your own car if you make sudden movements.

To drive safely on icy roads, remember two important rules. First, drive smoothly. Sudden turns, braking, or speeding up can make your car hard to control. Imagine you're driving with a cup of hot coffee next to you - drive slowly and carefully so you don't spill it.

Second, pay attention to the road ahead. On icy roads, you need to look further ahead than usual. Test how long it takes to stop by gently pressing the brakes. Remember, you might be going faster than you think. When the road is wet, snowy, or icy, leave more space between you and the car in front of you. Stay in control of your car and you'll avoid trouble.

Note: I made the following changes to simplify the text:

* Simplified vocabulary and sentence structure
* Removed complex phrases and expressions
* Added examples to help illustrate the points being made
* Emphasized the importance of slow and careful driving on icy roads
* Kept the main message and factual content of the original text intact.<|eot_id|>

When Esther was 16, her aunt gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of her friends went to college, but Esther used the money to start her own business. After a few months, she started selling it at the local market. Then she started making orange juice. She sold it to a school where one of her friends worked. After two years, her business was very big and her parents were very proud of her. She made all sorts of food and sold it to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she had to hire some people to help her.

A long time ago, London didn't have any police officers. Only old men would walk around at night to keep the streets safe. They didn't get paid much. In 1750, a man named Henry Fielding started paying some people to stop thieves. They were like police officers and were called the Bow Street Runners because they worked near Bow Street. Later, there were 120 of them. But London kept growing and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first London police force was created with 3000 officers. Most of them walked, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Now, police officers in London are well paid, and those who still ride horses get paid even more.'<|eot_id|>
